instruction: How did the researchers utilize machine learning models in their classification model for diagnosing tomato bacterial speck and bacterial spot on leaves using hyperspectral spectroscopy data?
Output: The researchers utilized machine learning models in their classification model by implementing a supervised machine learning algorithm called Support Vector Machine (SVM). They combined this algorithm with a normalizing pre-processing strategy and Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) to reduce the dimensionality of the hyperspectral spectroscopy data. This approach allowed them to develop an applied predictive classification model that could accurately classify tomato bacterial speck caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato (Pst) and bacterial spot caused by Xanthomonas euvesicatoria (Xeu) on leaves. The model achieved classification accuracies of 100% for Pst and 74% for Xeu before symptom appearance. These predictions were consistent with host-pathogen interactions mentioned in the literature and were supported by visual phenotyping inspection and PCR results.

instruction: Can hyperspectral spectroscopy (HS) data be considered superior to traditional methods for in-situ, non-destructive diagnosis of tomato bacterial speck and bacterial spot on leaves, based on the high classification accuracies achieved in the related study for in-situ, non-destructive diagnosis of tomato bacterial speck and bacterial spot on leaves?
